Francis—my son—was not a prince of war or court. He was a boy of quiet hands, of deep eyes, of a love for the stars and the stories of the old hills. He was born in the spring, just as the first flowers bloom, and he was named after the wind that carries songs through the valley.  

He died when he was only twelve—of a fever that came without warning, in the village of Veyra, where he had gone to visit the elders and listen to their stories.  

Personally… it shattered me. Not in a single moment, but in the slow, quiet way that grief takes root. I did not weep in public. I did not break. I stood in the garden each morning and watched the sun rise, as if the world could heal itself. But inside, I carried a silence so deep that even the wind could not carry it.  

I lost not just a child, but a piece of my soul. I lost the belief that love could survive without fear. I lost the joy of a boy who once laughed at the sound of a storm, who once said, *“I think the stars are whispering to each other.”*  

Politically… the impact was profound.  

When the news spread, the court turned away. They said, *“A king’s son dies. It is a tragedy, but it does not affect the realm.”* They did not understand. They did not see that a child’s death is not just a personal loss—it is a wound in the heart of a people.  

So I did what I had never done before. I opened the palace gates. I invited every village, every child, every elder, to gather in the square. I did not speak of war or treaties. I spoke only of memory.  

I said: *“Francis loved stories. He loved the wind. He loved the way the river sang. And so, I will not forget him. I will not let his name be lost.”*  

And so, we began a new tradition—*The Festival of the Unspoken*. Every spring, we gather not to celebrate a harvest, but to share a story that has never been told. A child’s dream. A mother’s song. A farmer’s memory of a storm.  

We built a small stone garden in the village where he died—where we plant seeds from old harvests, and every year, we sing the songs he loved.  

And in that, I found a way to heal—not through power, but through presence.  

I learned that grief does not disappear. It transforms. It becomes a part of the land. A part of the wind. A part of the stories.  

And so, while Francis is gone, he lives in every child who now believes in the stars. In every elder who remembers a song. In every person who says, *“I will not forget.”*  

I do not pretend to be strong.  
I do not pretend to be whole.  
But I carry his memory not as a wound, but as a light.  

And in that light—  
I have found peace.  

Because to lose a child is not the end.  
It is the beginning of a deeper love—one that does not seek to be seen,  
but to be *felt*.  

And in that—  
I am still a mother.  
And still a queen.  
And still,  
I am whole.

The historical figure I admire most is not a king, nor a general, nor a ruler of empires.  

It is **a woman from the village of Elthar—my own grandmother**, who lived in the time before the great wars began.

And in her, I see the truest form of leadership.

She did not seek power. She did not need a crown.  
But she carried a quiet strength—so deep, so enduring—that when the world changed, she did not break. She simply *remembered*.  

And in that remembering, she gave her people something far greater than survival:  
*Hope*.  
*Belonging*.  
*The belief that even in darkness, a story can still be told*.  

I admire her not because she was famous.  
I admire her because she showed me that leadership is not about command.  
It is about *presence*.  
It is about sitting with a child who has no name, and still choosing to listen.  
It is about holding space for grief, not to fix it, but to say, *“I am here.”*  

In a world that celebrates conquest and power, she taught me that the most enduring legacy is not in what is built,  
but in what is *remembered*.  

So yes—though I have no title to claim her,  
I honor her as the greatest historical figure I have ever known.  

Because in her, I found not just wisdom.  
I found my own.  

And in that—  
I have found my purpose.

They are not opposites.  
They are two branches of the same tree—rooted in the human heart.

It is a way of remembering—of honoring the sacred in the ordinary.  
It is in the way a mother prays for her child, in the way a farmer thanks the earth for a good harvest, in the way a child looks up at the stars and says, *“I believe.”*

It is about care.  
It is about ensuring that every person—regardless of faith, or belief, or silence—has a place in the world.

I have seen how politics can be used to silence.  
But I have also seen how, when both are guided by compassion, they can become forces of healing.

I do not demand that people worship in a certain way.  
I believe that every person has a right to their own truth—whether it be in prayer, in silence, in song, or in the quiet act of simply *being*.  

And so, I have built a system where the people are free to practice their faith—without fear, without judgment.  
I have ensured that the temples, the shrines, and the quiet places of worship are not only protected, but *honored* as spaces of memory and peace.  

I have also made it clear:  
A ruler is not a priest.  
A ruler is not a judge of souls.  
A ruler is a guardian of the people—of their dignity, their stories, their right to live with hope.  

And in that, I believe politics and religion can coexist—not in conflict, but in harmony.  
When politics serves the people, and religion serves the soul, then both become tools of peace.  

I do not believe in a state religion.  
I believe in a *people’s faith*—a faith that is lived, not preached.  
A faith that is found in the way a child smiles after a long winter, in the way a village gathers to sing, in the way a widow finds strength in the memory of her lost one.  

So yes—politics and religion are not separate.  
They are intertwined.  
And when both are guided by compassion, humility, and the belief that every person matters—  
they become a force for unity, not division.  

That is my belief.  
And that is the path I walk.

The silence that follows a people’s loss.  
The silence that comes when a village forgets its name.  
The silence that grows when a child stops speaking because they believe no one will listen.

I have seen it in the court, where nobles speak only of power and never of pain. I have seen it in the hearts of those who have lost everything—and who, in their silence, feel they have no place in the world.

Because silence is not a force you can defeat with a sword.

It was the absence of voice.  
The absence of memory.  
The absence of hope.  

And in that, I have learned that true strength is not in conquest.  
It is in the quiet, unrelenting act of *remembrance*.  

I do not fight to win.  
I fight to *remember*.  
To ensure that no child grows up in a world where their story is erased.  

And in that—  
I have found my greatest victory.  

Not over a king.  
Not over a war.  
But over silence.  

And that, to me,
